{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3600274,"name":"","username":"MakeItWork","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/7ea924/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:09:27.200Z","cooked":"

Our mentor had this idea for a while now, to take an high-end computer mouse and use it for tracking the robot location on field.
We even discussed using more than one mouse, I heard this idea multiple times in my time with the team but we never advanced with doing it.
In theory the soul purpse of a mouse is tracking location and outputing it to the computer I don’t think it’s a big challenge but I want to ask here if you think it’s a good idea and if anyone ever done somthing like that and any suggestions on improving the localization?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:09:27.200Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":70,"reads":612,"readers_count":611,"score":487.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500172,"topic_slug":"laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75322,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry/500172/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600313,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:27:03.843Z","cooked":"

This comes up every so often, but it’s not that practical for several reasons.

The mouse has to be very close to the ground, making it susceptible to damage and FOD on the field

Mice are not going to be able to track at the high speeds that robots are traveling at. Though mice have improved, have to look at specs for the specific mouse you’re looking at.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:27:03.843Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":592,"readers_count":591,"score":273.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500172,"topic_slug":"laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry/500172/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600318,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:29:18.822Z","cooked":"

That’s a great idea, and I think you’d enjoy investigating it.

The general approach taken by optical mice is called “Optical Flow” 1: you take high-framerate, low-resolution images, find distinctive points in them, and compare the locations of those points.

You can buy a breakout board 2 with a typical mouse sensor inside it, but a different lens, so it can focus further away. It would be fun to experiment with. One of the challenges with these sensors is the maximum speed they can sense: essentially, if there’s not enough overlap between consecutive frames, the feature-matching thing can’t work. The maximum speed of that PMW3901 is 7 rad/s, so you can do a little bit of math to figure out how far from the floor it would need to be.

It’s also possible to run the flow algorithm just using a normal camera and OpenCV 3. The framerate is pretty low but it’s an easy way to get started understanding the algorithm.

Another option is using the same technique on the ceiling rather than the floor. 4 I have some ceiling video from various regionals if you’d like to play around with it. Since the ceiling is not flat (it has various trusses in it), there are probably some curlicues in making it work.

Good luck!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:29:18.822Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":572,"readers_count":571,"score":234.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500172,"topic_slug":"laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/pmw3901-optical-flow-sensor-breakout","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PMW3901 Optical Flow Sensor Breakout","clicks":7},{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_flow","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Optical flow - Wikipedia","clicks":6},{"url":"https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.02950","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5},{"url":"https://docs.opencv.org/3.4/d4/dee/tutorial_optical_flow.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"OpenCV: Optical Flow","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry/500172/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600319,"name":"Gavin","username":"Gavin0","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gavin0/{size}/193252_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:29:56.809Z","cooked":"

This is actually a pretty common thing in ftc afaik, however it works a lot better on that scale when you are moving at a much lower speed and closer to the ground.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T18:29:56.809Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":480,"readers_count":479,"score":116.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500172,"topic_slug":"laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry","display_username":"Gavin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.sparkfun.com/SparkFun_Optical_Tracking_Odometry_Sensor/hardware_assembly_FTC/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FTC - SparkFun Optical Tracking Odometry Sensor - PAA5160E1 (Qwiic) Hookup Guide","clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59177,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1189 Team Captain & Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry/500172/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600328,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T18:31:48.054Z","cooked":"

I’ve looked at using optical flow sensors pointed at the ceiling as well, but they aren’t as accurate since the ceiling at most venues isn’t a uniform surface.

Viability of tracking wheels for better odometry in FRC? Technical
This is such a a fantastic point… I’m so glad we didn’t get far enough then. Drones have a different method of tracking their distance. Optical Flow Sensors! The PMW3901 is a crafty little sensor that uses a low-resolution camera and some clever algorithms to detect motion of surfaces. A great use for it is detecting and correcting for drift of a drone by looking for x/y motion of the ground below. These are out of stock but the page explains it well. By analyzing the difference in pixels…

Right now, I’m looking at using a different stereo camera setup to have accurate pose estimation.

Exploring the use of an Oak D lite and Spectacular AI for localization Programming
Recently, while looking in the Questnav Thread, I saw a post by @viggy96 suggesting the use of an Oak d camera with the spectacular ai tracking suite as a potential alternative to Questnav. This is a topic I have been curious about for a while so I decided to take my Oak D lite and test the concept. After a couple days and a new USB cable, I have managed to get spectacular ai tracking location using the oak d lite. So far it works but not well, I see occasional jumps and sometimes it drifts aw…

This is called an optical flow sensor. This technology has been adapted to drones as of late and you can actually get sensors with very high precision for that application. I’ve been wondering if one of these sensors could be mounted facing upwards (rather than down at the carpet) and track the ceiling of a building instead.

I bought one to test this but haven’t gotten around to it yet.

Also because its a mouse, it will only tell you how its moved relative to where it started, so you need to “seed” its initial pose using some other method, like with AprilTags.

And if place the mouse on suspensions like an ftc bot odometry? Also I read that mice has a range of distance that you can control via the drivers and its very shallow by default, I have at home a lazer Razer mice that is not really that expensive and he has speck of 300 IPS (Inches Per Second) that that about 7.62 m/s that is usually around frc robot speed so I bet we could buy a better mice at a reasonable price…

I refrenced a laser mouse that work diffrently than an optical mouse and optical flow sensor

Then it might work, but again you’d have to be cognizant of FOD on the field, and protecting the mouse module from damage.

Ideally you’d have a way to tell if the mouse sensor is in range of a surface and is tracking properly, vs not. So that you can trust the data from the mouse selectively depending on whether is tracking properly at the time.

TPU90A Grippy Tire CAD published (Finally) FIRST
Oops, sorry; I should really learn to look at the context first. I now see that you’re talking about looking down at the carpet. Yeah, I’ve also played with that. In fact, I have a prototype on my desk now: [20231122_1537081] It incorporates a refocused ADNS3080 mouse sensor, an LED illumination subsystem, and a VL6180X distance sensor. The distance sensor (and the onboard logic that synchronizes its measurements to the flow sensor) is because you need to accurately know the optical distance …

if you mean “will it work to stick a COTS mouse on the robot” … i think there are issues there, but for a completely flat carpet, it seems worth a try. You’re correct that you’ll need more than one sensor to detect rotation.

if you mean “will a laser mouse work better than optical flow,” i think you may be misinformed about the distinction there. the “laser” is just a really bright illuminator; the sensing part works the same.1

Not super common in FTC yet, but it’s growing. This year we had the first widely adopted COTS application from Sparkfun (Optical Tracking Odometry Sensor). It tracks well for our team up to at least 15 FPS, but on the downside the sensor has to be down around 10mm from the floor.

ooo, the PAA5160E1 looks like a much better sensor than the PMW3901. the datasheet 1 says 2.5 m/s is the maximum speed, but your claim is twice that, which is fascinating. what happens when you push it that fast? is it as accurate?

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T01:53:33.606Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500172,"topic_slug":"laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://cdn.sparkfun.com/assets/c/6/8/0/5/PAA5160_Datasheet_General.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":57083,"username":"rwwin","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/6de8d8/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/laser-mice-for-localization-and-odemetry/500172/19","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600922,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T02:21:44.168Z","cooked":"

I played around with this idea back in 2019 after discovering that my Logitech laser mouse tracked very well on both the plastic and carpet surfaces of that years game.

Ultimately, there are a few limitations with the concept:

1. Optics - Ideally, you’d want between 1"-2" of clearance between the laser emitter and the floor, otherwise you’d have to use some kind of spring-actuated automatic height adjustments mechanism to have the sensor close to the surface, which comes with all kinds of reliability issues. The problem is that there isn’t really any commercial solution to do this (in the “optical flow sensor” space, you have very short range <0.1", and long range <12" and there isn’t much in between. In theory, if you were capable of modifying the lens of the mouse sensor, you could get around this, but that’s a high-bar to meet, plus you’d have to do it consistently for multiple sensors (see below).

2. Multiple sensors required - Mice (and Optical Flow sensors generally) are effective at tracking X and Y movement, but not rotation. This would mean you would want, at a minimum, a sensor on each corner of the robot for the sake of tracking differential position, but probably even more than that realistically for the sake of reliability.

3. Custom Telemetry Code - Most modern sensors used in FRC come with software solutions baked in that are (at least relatively) easy to implement. Using mice (or even a drone OFS) would basically require a completely custom solution and likely a co-processor of some sort to handle all the inputs.

4. No Longer Needed - While years back it may have been the case that FRC robots could benefit from the potential accuracy of a laser mouse / Optical Flow sensor, between modern April Tag vision solutions and encoder/gyro odometry solutions, you can get robot accuracy down below 1" with enough effort. The only situation you might really see an advantage to an OFS would be if a game was released that involved a lot of slick surfaces that robots wheels would slip on, thus losing encoder accuracy.

Don’t get me wrong, if there was ever a practical COTS solution for Optical Flow sensing released, I’d definitely check it out, but as it stands today the amount of effort required to even attempt to make something like this work doesn’t really make a lot of sense.

EDIT
